May nilpotence

Apr 24, 2020

(As of June, I’ve made some edits to this post.)

I’ve been working on understanding the nilpotence theorem better. In my recent paper, I sketched out a proof of nilpotence which relates to the construction of certain higher chromatic Thom spectra. I am currently writing another paper where I expand on this argument; this paper is basically an exposition of the proof of the nilpotence theorem, but it will have some “new” stuff.

In this post, I would like to sketch a proof of a result related to the May nilpotence conjecture, which goes along the lines of the proof of the nilpotence theorem. I’ve been sitting on this post for a while, but figure it’s time to post it. The May nilpotence conjecture was already proven by Mathew-Naumann-Noel, but the argument provided here is different (and also incomplete, but I think it can be completed). I will detail the analogies to the nilpotence theorem at the end of the post. In any case, here’s the statement of the theorem.

Theorem (May nilpotence): Let be an -ring, and is killed by the integral Hurewicz map. Then is nilpotent.

In other words, detects nilpotence for -rings. (As is usual, we shall -localize everywhere.)

The observation that I’d like to utilize for this is the Dold-Thom theorem, which states that is the infinite symmetric power . This is the filtered colimit of the partial symmetric powers . If , then the map factors through for some . By replacing with its localization , we can instead try to show that if is an -ring such that , then .

There is a cofiber sequence , it suffices to show that . The spectrum is also known as (or rather, ). It is the Steinberg idempotent applied to the Thom space , where is the reduced regular representation of dimension .

[Recall that, in general, is the Steinberg idempotent applied to the Thom spectrum . The integer roughly detects the chromatic height. For instance, if denotes the Bousfield-Kuhn functor, then can be solved by a sequence of spectra with fibers for , where is the cofiber of .]

The fact that means that for all . So, we need to show that this implies that . For this, we might like to argue as in the proof of the nilpotence theorem. To do so, we state the following conjecture, whose discussion will comprise the remainder of this post.

Conjecture: Let denote the -skeleton of . The following statements are true.

  1. There is an equality .

  2. is a type spectrum, and there is a -self map of whose cofiber is Bousfield equivalent to .

One remark: as stated, the conjecture’s probably only true for . For smaller primes, you have to modify the dimension of the skeleta. I haven’t yet worked out the numbers.

Note that, in part (2), if is a type spectrum, then the periodicity theorem implies the second half of part (2). But part of the conjecture is that this can be proven without appealing to the periodicity theorem. Why does this matter? The entire point of this approach to the May nilpotence theorem is to avoid appealing to the nilpotence theorem (or its consequences, like periodicity), and to emphasize that a modification of the proof works in this -setting too.

This conjecture doesn’t actually imply the May nilpotence theorem or our desired variant (even though I had claimed this in a previous version of the post) — but it looks very plausible, and seems to be related to some other deep observations in this area. Why should the conjecture be true? Let me discuss part (2) first. When , this is saying that there’s a self-map of the sphere whose cofiber is Bousfield equivalent to the -skeleton of . But this is true: just take the degree map! When , this is saying that there’s a self-map of finite stunted projective spaces (or skeleta of ) whose cofiber is Bousfield equivalent to a skeleton of . The -skeleton of is the mod Moore spectrum, and this has a -self map whose cofiber is a (generalized) mod -Moore spectrum. But the -skeleton of is the mod -Moore spectrum , at least for .

What about part (1)? Well, part (1) is obvious when … It’s a lot more nontrivial when ; in this case, it states that has the same Bousfield class as . At least when , this is an unpublished result of Mike Hopkins’, whose proof I have not yet internalized.

Note that one corollary of the conjecture is the following (whose statement is sufficient to imply May nilpotence, by the preceding discussion): . Psychologically, at least for me, this looks a lot harder to prove than the two parts of the conjecture.

So how does this relate to the proof of the nilpotence theorem? More generally, there is an analogy between the and -worlds, which seems to play out as in the following table. The last few rows don’t have anything to do with nilpotence.

”/-world” ”/-world”
nilpotence May nilpotence
/chromatic filtration /filtration via the Goodwillie tower of the identity
cofiber sequences constructing as -module the Takayasu cofiber sequence
“Step III” of nilpotence, i.e., Bousfield class of -module skeleton of is the Bousfield class of conjecture made above
Smith’s type spectra as a summand of (for ) corresponding to an idempotent of Mitchell’s type spectra as summands corresponding to the Steinberg idempotent of
(in algebraic geometry) the Ran space (in algebraic geometry) the (lci) Hilbert scheme
